document.docAuthor: Cai, Yanpeng, Li, Xiaoyan & Zhou, Hongzhang
document.docTitle: Queskallion saetosum Cai & Li & Zhou 2020, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Queskallion Smetana, 2015 (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Quediina) from China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Queskallion Smetana, 2015 (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Quediina) from China

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Morphological Laboratory, Guizhou University of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Guiyang, 550025, Guizhou, China
Hebei Key Laboratory of Animal Diversity, Langfang Normal University Aiminxidao 100, Anci Area, Langfang 065000, Hebei Province, China

Key Laboratory of Zoological Systematics and Evolution, Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 1 Beichen West Rd., Chaoyang District, Beijing 100101, China & University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, 19 A Yuquan Rd., Shijingshan District, Beijing, 100049, China

figureCitation.captionText: Figure 1. Q. saetosum sp. nov., morphology A head B pronotum C elytra D underside of paramere E apical portion of median lobe, parameral view. Scale bars: 1 mm (A-C); 0.20 mm (D, E).

Figure 2. Q. saetosum sp. nov., morphology A male sternite VIII B male sternite IX C male tergite X D apical portion of median lobe, parameral view E underside of paramere F aedeagus, lateral view G aedeagus, parameral view H female tergite X. Scale bars: 0.20 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Holotype : China • ♂; Sichuan Province, Baoxing County, Longdong, Ruobigou; alt. 1600 m; 10 August 2003; Xiaodong Yu (IZ-CAS) leg. Paratypes : 3 ♂♂, 1 ♀; same locality as holotype; 10-13 August 2003; Xiaodong Yu (IZ-CAS) leg.

This new species is very similar to
Q. tangi
Smetana in all characters, but it can be distinguished from the latter by having the male paramere of the aedeagus slightly narrower than the median lobe, underside with sensory peg setae arranged into one characteristic inversed Y-shaped figure, female tergite X with apical margin forming distinctive M-shaped indention; whereas the latter has male paramere of aedeagus with subapical portion slightly dilated laterally becoming wider than median lobe, underside with sensory peg setae arranged into two S-like figures, female tergite X with apical margin deeply and arcuately emarginated.

Head dark brown to blackish brown; pronotum, scutellum and elytra dark brown; abdomen dark brown, each tergite with posterior margin slightly paler; head, pronotum and abdomen strongly iridescent; antennae dark brown, labrum yellowish-brown, mandibles dark brown, maxillary and labial palpi dark brown; legs dark brown.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 1.
Q. saetosum
sp. nov., morphology A head B pronotum C elytra D underside of paramere E apical portion of median lobe, parameral view. Scale bars: 1 mm ( A-C ); 0.20 mm ( D, E ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Abdominal tergite II finely punctate; setiferous punctures of other tergites finer and sparser than those of elytra, distinctly becoming sparser toward posterior margin of each tergite, and generally becoming so toward apex of abdomen; tergite VII with whitish apical seam of palisade setae.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 2.
Q. saetosum
sp. nov., morphology A male sternite VIII B male sternite IX C male tergite X D apical portion of median lobe, parameral view E underside of paramere F aedeagus, lateral view G aedeagus, parameral view H female tergite X. Scale bars: 0.20 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Queskallion saetosum
sp. nov. is at present known only from the type locality in central Sichuan Province (Fig. 3 ), China, at an altitude of 1600 m. The specimens were collected from stacks of withered grass on the roadside in August.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 3. Known distribution of
Queskallion
species in China, Myanmar and Nepal.

subSubSection.paragraph: The specific name is from the Latin adjective saetosus , - a , - um (bristly), referring to the additional setae on the pronotum.
